**Hot Spot** is a MIT-licensed mod that displays better thermal data to the user.

**Download**

- [<abbr title="Comprehensive Kerbal Archive Network (a KSP mod manager)"><abbr title="Comprehensive Kerbal Archive Network (a KSP mod manager)">CKAN</abbr></abbr>](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/90246-/) as HotSpot
- [GitHub](https://github.com/Apokee/HotSpot/releases)

**Information**

- For more information and installation instructions please see the [**README**](https://github.com/Apokee/HotSpot/blob/master/README.md).
- For changes please see **[CHANGELOG](https://github.com/Apokee/HotSpot/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md)**.
- For future enhancements please see [**GitHub issues**](https://github.com/Apokee/HotSpot/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3Aenhancement).

**Source:** [GitHub](https://github.com/Apokee/HotSpot)

**License:** [MIT](https://github.com/Apokee/HotSpot/blob/master/LICENSE.md)

Thank you so much for this! I have been wanting this mod since I first saw the stock heat-overlay!

So I have this vessel, it's 4 separate launches, docked into one ship for a big old mission. I'm getting this weird effect when trying to enable the overlay, for some reason it's only showing me the overlay on the last piece that was docked to the others.

The right-click temp info for individual parts works ok for everything else, it's just the overlay that seems borked:

![PU7hH6h.png](http://i.imgur.com/PU7hH6h.png)
What are the temps of the highlighted and non-highlighted parts respectively?

> 
> What are the temps of the highlighted and non-highlighted parts respectively?

![hhSvhBP.png](http://i.imgur.com/hhSvhBP.png)

![7fm2ahd.png](http://i.imgur.com/7fm2ahd.png)

This is strange, I usually test all my contraptions in sandbox before I spend all the time launching and docking in career. So I have another version of this craft that I assembled in the VAB and HyperEdited into space as one ship and it behaves normally when trying to enable the heat overlay. It's only the separately launched and docked version in career that acts weird like in the pics....

Well the good news is that unless there's a bug in the temperature display (highly unlikely, it just reads the temperature right off the part) the overlay is accurate. By default anything below 273.2K (freezing point of water) will be blue transitioning to purple the colder it is. The unhighlighted parts are ~287-289K, basically room temperature, where the color gradient transitions to fully transparent so there's effectively no color.

Why those parts are so much colder than the others I couldn't begin to say, I just show the data. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif) I would guess maybe because those parts were in space much longer so they had time to cool down radiatively, but if I read your initial post correctly the cooler parts were the more recently launched ones? /me shrugs

It does make sense that other parts in space longer would be cooler. Now that you've mentioned it, I could be mistaken on which part was brought up last. I should have marked them somehow! The first piece up was one of the long sections, then the 2 in the middle, then the other longer section was docked last. 

I've been actually thinking that the entire craft is bugged somehow, the temp gauge shows correctly, it's just the colors that are not showing up. I'll continue on with the mission and see what happens, I had just finished docking and decided to check the temps when I saw this anomaly ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

(EDIT) --> So I quicksaved and did a long burn, and the color overlay worked just like it should. I think maybe I was so used to seeing the stock overlay where the entire craft starts out red, that I didn't take into account the different pieces being put together having different temps. Once I fired it up, it all evened out normally and worked like I expected it should. Now if Squad would work on docking ports not transferring heat ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

I've implemented support for all 5 kinds of thermal rateÃ‚Â¹ in both the context menu and overlay, but I'm waiting on 1.0.3 and it's potentially breaking changes to the thermal system to release it. See this [README](https://github.com/Apokee/HotSpot/blob/develop/README.md) for info. I've also renamed the mod to Hot Spot, and it'll be fairly easy to add support for other metrics (not just thermal data) in the future.

Ã‚Â¹*To my understanding, the way KSP uses "flux" is this context is a misnomer. A flux is a change in some quantity per unit area. From what I can see all of KSP's "flux" measurements are simply changes in energy per unit time (i.e. a power), so I've chosen to avoid using the word "flux".*

- - - Updated - - -

BTW, if you want to give the new version a try you can download a nightly build from [here](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/Apokee/hotspot/build/24/job/405cy6chniv5e2h4/artifacts); remove the EhancedThermalData folder of course. This is not an official release of course and will very likely break with 1.0.3.

v0.2.0 is out now for KSP 1.0.3 and has been renamed to "Hot Spot". Big features in this release are support for thermal rate metrics and configuration settings from a GUI accessible from the AppLauncher (settings will be made persistent in a future version).
I don't want to be picky.... but heat glowing in real life goes from red, to orange to white glowing hot.

> 
> I don't want to be picky.... but heat glowing in real life goes from red, to orange to white glowing hot.

Yes, and as mentioned in the README that's the black body color scheme that KSP defaults to... which is not very intuitive. This isn't a representation of black body radiation, it's a informational overlay designed to provide information to the user at a glance; when you see something red, you don't think "cool". Instead I've used a color scheme inspired by [weather maps](https://4.bp.blogspot.com/_pczy2obwPYM/TOtnPY-FmZI/AAAAAAAAAhA/veKtlxLEQLE/s1600/eta_sfc_st_69_tempfall.gif) that's significantly more intuitive: *red is hot; blue is cold*.

>

>
